Award.AwardTitle: Understanding Interstellar Aromatic Chemistry: An Integrated Experimental, Theoretical, and Astronomical Approach
Award.AbstractNarration: Molecules are identified in space with radio telescopes by matching emission signals with precise laboratory measurements made on Earth. Using this coordinated effort, more than 200 molecules, many containing carbon ? an element central to life ? have been identified in our Milky Way galaxy. In this research effort, scientists will make new laboratory measurements of large carbon-bearing molecules that might be detected with radio telescopes. Once very precise measurements of the molecules? unique signature are made in the laboratory, scientists will use radio telescopes to search for evidence of the same signals in space. <br/><br/>They will search for these new molecules primarily in large clouds of gas which are widely believed to be the birthplace of stars. These clouds are extremely cold (within a few degrees of absolute zero) and have very low density but are known to harbor a rich inventory of small carbon molecules. From these observations, scientists will learn what types of molecules can be formed in space under extreme conditions. These observations are used to infer the pathways by which more complex molecules are synthesized under such inhospitable conditions. Molecules with cyclic or ring shapes are of interest because they are especially stable, commonly serving as the building blocks for larger molecules such as pharmaceutical drugs, polymers, and DNA on Earth.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complex organic chemistry recently discovered in the interstellar medium (ISM) — the space between stars — has exposed profound gaps in our understanding of the cosmic evolution of carbon.This award has sought to address this remarkable conundrum: how does interstellar organic material evolve from small molecular precursors to five- and six-membered carbon rings — the basic building blocks of organic chemistry  — under extreme conditions of temperature,  within a few degrees of absolute zero, and pressure, with a nearly perfect vacuum? By means of a closely-coordinated research program that combines laboratory measurements, theoretical calculations, and astronomical observations with large radio telescopes, significant advances in answering this basic question have been made.

 
Based on radio-frequency emission features observed with sensitive radio telescopes, specifically the 100 m Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) in Green Bank, West Virginia, US, our group and collaborators have detected the existence of over a dozen large new organic molecules in the ISM.  These identifications have been made with very high confidence because the unique spectral fingerprint of each of these molecules measured in the laboratory agrees in frequency to within a fraction of a linewidth with multiple and similarly sharp emission features from space.  The number of new detections is noteworthy not only because it represents roughly 5\% of the known chemical inventory in space, but because it includes the largest and most chemically complex molecules ever found in molecular clouds. These discoveries include the first bicyclic rings (indene and cyanonapthalene), providing crucial insights into the chemical pathways by which complex two-dimensional carbon forms and evolves in space.


Detecting and characterizing specific interstellar molecules relies critically on highly precise (better than 1 part per million) laboratory measurements of their radio (microwave and millimeter-wave) emission frequencies.We have advanced and developed new laboratory techniques for generating, detecting, and analyzing the microwave spectra of complex gas mixtures during this award.These mixtures contain 100s of unique chemical compounds, many highly reactive, short-lived species.The sheer richness of spectroscopic data has required new automated data collection and analysis approaches. Sophisticated high-speed spectral fitting algorithms and machine-learning-based assignment and modeling software have also been developed in our group to meet this challenge.These tools enable thousands of molecular features in complex chemical mixtures to be exhaustively assigned and analyzed with minimal human intervention. This comprehensive, unbiased approach has proven highly productive and, complemented by related studies conducted during this award, has provided the requisite laboratory data for the astronomical discovery of 15 new interstellar molecules by us and other groups.  Furthermore, many other molecules recently detected and characterized in our laboratory will likely be found in space as more sensitive astronomical surveys are performed and as even larger and more sensitive radio telescopes come online. 


Our studies establish that complex organic chemistry is ubiquitous in the ISM, but specific chemical pathways remain poorly understood. Because the most reactive species that drive this chemistry are extremely challenging to detect, future work to constrain astrochemical models will require significant but achievable improvements in the sensitivity of laboratory measurements and astronomical observations. The approach developed in our laboratory provides a firm foundation for continued advances in our understanding of primordial carbon chemistry.


An important aspect of our research program is the emphasis placed on student training and mentorship. Over the award period, our laboratory hosted five undergraduate and high school student scientists who completed research projects in a hands-on, interdisciplinary environment, which in some cases led to authorship on a peer-reviewed publication. These students gained valuable scientific, laboratory, analytical, and communication skills that have prepared them to take the next step in their education and careers.
